standard_metadata.standard_description: Add, subtract, multiply, and divide decimals to hundredths, using concrete models or drawings and strategies based on place value, properties of operations, and/or the relationship between addition and subtraction; relate the strategy to a written method and explain the reasoning used.
standard_metadata.standard_title: Divide whole numbers to get a decimal (2-digit divisors)

hints.content: Let's rewrite the division problem as a fraction. Then we can split the fraction into better known fractions.
$\begin{align} 78\div  12&=\dfrac{78}{12}&\small\gray{\text{Rewrite the division as a fraction.}} \end{align}$
$\begin{align} 78\div  12&=\dfrac{78}{12}&\small\gray{\text{Rewrite the division as a fraction.}}\\\\ &=\dfrac{72 + 6}{12}&\small\gray{\text{Split 78 into 72 and 6.}} \end{align}$

$\begin{align} 78\div  12&=\dfrac{78}{12}&\small\gray{\text{Rewrite the division as a fraction.}}\\\\ &=\dfrac{72 + 6}{12}&\small\gray{\text{Split 78 into 72 and 6.}}\\\\ &=\dfrac{72}{12} + \dfrac{6}{12}&\small\gray{\text{Break into two fractions.}} \end{align}$

$\begin{align} 78\div  12&=\dfrac{78}{12}&\small\gray{\text{Rewrite the division as a fraction.}}\\\\ &=\dfrac{72 + 6}{12}&\small\gray{\text{Split 78 into 72 and 6.}}\\\\ &=\dfrac{72}{12} + \dfrac{6}{12}&\small\gray{\text{Break into two fractions.}}\\\\ &=6 + \dfrac12&\small\gray{\text{Simplify.}} \end{align}$

$\begin{align} 78\div  12&=\dfrac{78}{12}&\small\gray{\text{Rewrite the division as a fraction.}}\\\\ &=\dfrac{72 + 6}{12}&\small\gray{\text{Split 78 into 72 and 6.}}\\\\ &=\dfrac{72}{12} + \dfrac{6}{12}&\small\gray{\text{Break into two fractions.}}\\\\ &=6 + \dfrac12&\small\gray{\text{Simplify.}}\\\\ &=6 + 0.5&\small\gray{\text{Write as a decimal.}} \end{align}$

$\begin{align} 78\div  12&=\dfrac{78}{12}&\small\gray{\text{Rewrite the division as a fraction.}}\\\\ &=\dfrac{72 + 6}{12}&\small\gray{\text{Split 78 into 72 and 6.}}\\\\ &=\dfrac{72}{12} + \dfrac{6}{12}&\small\gray{\text{Break into two fractions.}}\\\\ &=6 + \dfrac12&\small\gray{\text{Simplify.}}\\\\ &=6 + 0.5&\small\gray{\text{Add.}}\\\\ &=6.5 \end{align}$
Let's rewrite the division problem as a fraction. Then we can split the fraction into better known fractions.
$\begin{align} 63 \div 12&=\dfrac{63}{12}&\small\gray{\text{Rewrite the division as a fraction.}} \end{align}$
$\begin{align} 63 \div 12&=\dfrac{63}{12}&\small\gray{\text{Rewrite the division as a fraction.}}\\\\ &=\dfrac{60 + 3}{12}&\small\gray{\text{Split 63 into 60 and 3.}} \end{align}$

$\begin{align} 63 \div 12&=\dfrac{63}{12}&\small\gray{\text{Rewrite the division as a fraction.}}\\\\ &=\dfrac{60 + 3}{12}&\small\gray{\text{Split 63 into 60 and 3.}}\\\\ &=\dfrac{60}{12} + \dfrac{3}{12}&\small\gray{\text{Break into two fractions.}} \end{align}$

$\begin{align} 63 \div 12&=\dfrac{63}{12}&\small\gray{\text{Rewrite the division as a fraction.}}\\\\ &=\dfrac{60 + 3}{12}&\small\gray{\text{Split 63 into 60 and 3.}}\\\\ &=\dfrac{60}{12} + \dfrac{3}{12}&\small\gray{\text{Break into two fractions.}}\\\\ &=5 + \dfrac{1}{4}&\small\gray{\text{Simplify.}} \end{align}$

$\begin{align} 63 \div 12&=\dfrac{63}{12}&\small\gray{\text{Rewrite the division as a fraction.}}\\\\ &=\dfrac{60 + 3}{12}&\small\gray{\text{Split 63 into 60 and 3.}}\\\\ &=\dfrac{60}{12} + \dfrac{3}{12}&\small\gray{\text{Break into two fractions.}}\\\\ &=5 + \dfrac{1}{4}&\small\gray{\text{Simplify.}}\\\\ &=5 + 0.25&\small\gray{\text{Write as a decimal.}} \end{align}$

$\begin{align} 63 \div 12&=\dfrac{63}{12}&\small\gray{\text{Rewrite the division as a fraction.}}\\\\ &=\dfrac{60 + 3}{12}&\small\gray{\text{Split 63 into 60 and 3.}}\\\\ &=\dfrac{60}{12} + \dfrac{3}{12}&\small\gray{\text{Break into two fractions.}}\\\\ &=5 + \dfrac{1}{4}&\small\gray{\text{Simplify.}}\\\\ &=5 + 0.25&\small\gray{\text{Write as a decimal.}}\\\\ &=5.25 \end{align}$
Let's rewrite the division problem as a fraction. Then we can split the fraction into better known fractions.
$\begin{align} 306 \div 45&=\dfrac{306}{45}&\small\gray{\text{Rewrite the division as a fraction.}} \end{align}$
$\begin{align} 306 \div 45&=\dfrac{306}{45}&\small\gray{\text{Rewrite the division as a fraction.}}\\\\ &=\dfrac{34}{5} \times \dfrac{9}{9}&\small\gray{\text{Rewrite as a product.}} \end{align}$

$\begin{align} 306 \div 45&=\dfrac{306}{45}&\small\gray{\text{Rewrite the division as a fraction.}}\\\\ &=\dfrac{34}{5} \times \dfrac{9}{9}&\small\gray{\text{Rewrite as a product.}}\\\\ &=\dfrac{34}{5} \times 1&\small\gray{\text{Simplify.}} \end{align}$

$\begin{align} 306 \div 45&=\dfrac{306}{45}&\small\gray{\text{Rewrite the division as a fraction.}}\\\\ &=\dfrac{34}{5} \times \dfrac{9}{9}&\small\gray{\text{Rewrite as a product.}}\\\\ &=\dfrac{34}{5} \times 1&\small\gray{\text{Simplify.}}\\\\ &=\dfrac{30 + 4}{5}&\small\gray{\text{Split 34 into 30 and 4.}} \end{align}$

$\begin{align} 306 \div 45&=\dfrac{306}{45}&\small\gray{\text{Rewrite the division as a fraction.}}\\\\ &=\dfrac{34}{5} \times \dfrac{9}{9}&\small\gray{\text{Rewrite as a product.}}\\\\ &=\dfrac{34}{5} \times 1&\small\gray{\text{Simplify.}}\\\\ &=\dfrac{30 + 4}{5}&\small\gray{\text{Split 34 into 30 and 4.}}\\\\ &=\dfrac{30}{5} + \dfrac{4}{5}&\small\gray{\text{Break into two fractions.}} \end{align}$

$\begin{align} 306 \div 45&=\dfrac{306}{45}&\small\gray{\text{Rewrite the division as a fraction.}}\\\\ &=\dfrac{34}{5} \times \dfrac{9}{9}&\small\gray{\text{Rewrite as a product.}}\\\\ &=\dfrac{34}{5} \times 1&\small\gray{\text{Simplify.}}\\\\ &=\dfrac{30 + 4}{5}&\small\gray{\text{Split 34 into 30 and 4.}}\\\\ &=\dfrac{30}{5} + \dfrac{4}{5}&\small\gray{\text{Break into two fractions.}}\\\\ &=6 + \dfrac{4}{5}&\small\gray{\text{Simplify.}} \end{align}$

$\begin{align} 306 \div 45&=\dfrac{306}{45}&\small\gray{\text{Rewrite the division as a fraction.}}\\\\ &=\dfrac{34}{5} \times \dfrac{9}{9}&\small\gray{\text{Rewrite as a product.}}\\\\ &=\dfrac{34}{5} \times 1&\small\gray{\text{Simplify.}}\\\\ &=\dfrac{30 + 4}{5}&\small\gray{\text{Split 34 into 30 and 4.}}\\\\ &=\dfrac{30}{5} + \dfrac{4}{5}&\small\gray{\text{Break into two fractions.}}\\\\ &=6 + \dfrac{4}{5}&\small\gray{\text{Simplify.}}\\\\ &=6 + 0.8 &\small\gray{\text{Write as a decimal.}} \end{align}$

$\begin{align} 306 \div 45&=\dfrac{306}{45}&\small\gray{\text{Rewrite the division as a fraction.}}\\\\ &=\dfrac{34}{5} \times \dfrac{9}{9}&\small\gray{\text{Rewrite as a product.}}\\\\ &=\dfrac{34}{5} \times 1&\small\gray{\text{Simplify.}}\\\\ &=\dfrac{30 + 4}{5}&\small\gray{\text{Split 34 into 30 and 4.}}\\\\ &=\dfrac{30}{5} + \dfrac{4}{5}&\small\gray{\text{Break into two fractions.}}\\\\ &=6 + \dfrac{4}{5}&\small\gray{\text{Simplify.}}\\\\ &=6 + 0.8 &\small\gray{\text{Write as a decimal.}}\\\\ &=6.8 \end{align}$
Let's rewrite the division problem as a fraction. Then we can split the fraction into better known fractions.
$\begin{align} 98 \div 56&=\dfrac{98}{56}&\small\gray{\text{Rewrite the division as a fraction.}} \end{align}$
$\begin{align} 98 \div 56&=\dfrac{98}{56}&\small\gray{\text{Rewrite the division as a fraction.}}\\\\ &=\dfrac{14}{8} \times \dfrac{7}{7}&\small\gray{\text{Rewrite as a product.}} \end{align}$

$\begin{align} 98 \div 56&=\dfrac{98}{56}&\small\gray{\text{Rewrite the division as a fraction.}}\\\\ &=\dfrac{14}{8} \times \dfrac{7}{7}&\small\gray{\text{Rewrite as a product.}}\\\\ &=\dfrac{7}{4} \times 1&\small\gray{\text{Simplify.}} \end{align}$

$\begin{align} 98 \div 56&=\dfrac{98}{56}&\small\gray{\text{Rewrite the division as a fraction.}}\\\\ &=\dfrac{14}{8} \times \dfrac{7}{7}&\small\gray{\text{Rewrite as a product.}}\\\\ &=\dfrac{7}{4} \times 1&\small\gray{\text{Simplify.}}\\\\ &=\dfrac{4 + 3}{4}&\small\gray{\text{Split 7 into 4 and 3.}} \end{align}$

$\begin{align} 98 \div 56&=\dfrac{98}{56}&\small\gray{\text{Rewrite the division as a fraction.}}\\\\ &=\dfrac{14}{8} \times \dfrac{7}{7}&\small\gray{\text{Rewrite as a product.}}\\\\ &=\dfrac{7}{4} \times 1&\small\gray{\text{Simplify.}}\\\\ &=\dfrac{4 + 3}{4}&\small\gray{\text{Split 7 into 4 and 3.}}\\\\ &=\dfrac{4}{4} + \dfrac{3}{4}&\small\gray{\text{Break into two fractions.}} \end{align}$

$\begin{align} 98 \div 56&=\dfrac{98}{56}&\small\gray{\text{Rewrite the division as a fraction.}}\\\\ &=\dfrac{14}{8} \times \dfrac{7}{7}&\small\gray{\text{Rewrite as a product.}}\\\\ &=\dfrac{7}{4} \times 1&\small\gray{\text{Simplify.}}\\\\ &=\dfrac{4 + 3}{4}&\small\gray{\text{Split 7 into 4 and 3.}}\\\\ &=\dfrac{4}{4} + \dfrac{3}{4}&\small\gray{\text{Break into two fractions.}}\\\\ &=1 + \dfrac{3}{4}&\small\gray{\text{Simplify.}} \end{align}$

$\begin{align} 98 \div 56&=\dfrac{98}{56}&\small\gray{\text{Rewrite the division as a fraction.}}\\\\ &=\dfrac{14}{8} \times \dfrac{7}{7}&\small\gray{\text{Rewrite as a product.}}\\\\ &=\dfrac{7}{4} \times 1&\small\gray{\text{Simplify.}}\\\\ &=\dfrac{4 + 3}{4}&\small\gray{\text{Split 7 into 4 and 3.}}\\\\ &=\dfrac{4}{4} + \dfrac{3}{4}&\small\gray{\text{Break into two fractions.}}\\\\ &=1 + \dfrac{3}{4}&\small\gray{\text{Simplify.}}\\\\ &=1 + 0.75 &\small\gray{\text{Write as a decimal.}} \end{align}$

$\begin{align} 98 \div 56&=\dfrac{98}{56}&\small\gray{\text{Rewrite the division as a fraction.}}\\\\ &=\dfrac{14}{8} \times \dfrac{7}{7}&\small\gray{\text{Rewrite as a product.}}\\\\ &=\dfrac{7}{4} \times 1&\small\gray{\text{Simplify.}}\\\\ &=\dfrac{4 + 3}{4}&\small\gray{\text{Split 7 into 4 and 3.}}\\\\ &=\dfrac{4}{4} + \dfrac{3}{4}&\small\gray{\text{Break into two fractions.}}\\\\ &=1 + \dfrac{3}{4}&\small\gray{\text{Simplify.}}\\\\ &=1 + 0.75 &\small\gray{\text{Write as a decimal.}}\\\\ &=1.75 \end{align}$
Let's rewrite the division problem as a fraction. Then we can split the fraction into better known fractions.
$\begin{align} 606 \div 15&=\dfrac{606}{15}&\small\gray{\text{Rewrite the division as a fraction.}} \end{align}$
$\begin{align} 606 \div 15&=\dfrac{606}{15}&\small\gray{\text{Rewrite the division as a fraction.}}\\\\ &=\dfrac{202}{5} \times \dfrac{3}{3}&\small\gray{\text{Rewrite as a product.}} \end{align}$

$\begin{align} 606 \div 15&=\dfrac{606}{15}&\small\gray{\text{Rewrite the division as a fraction.}}\\\\ &=\dfrac{202}{5} \times \dfrac{3}{3}&\small\gray{\text{Rewrite as a product.}}\\\\ &=\dfrac{202}{5} \times 1&\small\gray{\text{Simplify.}} \end{align}$

$\begin{align} 606 \div 15&=\dfrac{606}{15}&\small\gray{\text{Rewrite the division as a fraction.}}\\\\ &=\dfrac{202}{5} \times \dfrac{3}{3}&\small\gray{\text{Rewrite as a product.}}\\\\ &=\dfrac{202}{5} \times 1&\small\gray{\text{Simplify.}}\\\\ &=\dfrac{200 + 2}{5}&\small\gray{\text{Split 202 into 200 and 2.}} \end{align}$

$\begin{align} 606 \div 15&=\dfrac{606}{15}&\small\gray{\text{Rewrite the division as a fraction.}}\\\\ &=\dfrac{202}{5} \times \dfrac{3}{3}&\small\gray{\text{Rewrite as a product.}}\\\\ &=\dfrac{202}{5} \times 1&\small\gray{\text{Simplify.}}\\\\ &=\dfrac{200 + 2}{5}&\small\gray{\text{Split 202 into 200 and 2.}}\\\\ &=\dfrac{200}{5} + \dfrac{2}{5}&\small\gray{\text{Break into two fractions.}} \end{align}$

$\begin{align} 606 \div 15&=\dfrac{606}{15}&\small\gray{\text{Rewrite the division as a fraction.}}\\\\ &=\dfrac{202}{5} \times \dfrac{3}{3}&\small\gray{\text{Rewrite as a product.}}\\\\ &=\dfrac{202}{5} \times 1&\small\gray{\text{Simplify.}}\\\\ &=\dfrac{200 + 2}{5}&\small\gray{\text{Split 202 into 200 and 2.}}\\\\ &=\dfrac{200}{5} + \dfrac{2}{5}&\small\gray{\text{Break into two fractions.}}\\\\ &=40 + \dfrac{2}{5}&\small\gray{\text{Simplify.}} \end{align}$

$\begin{align} 606 \div 15&=\dfrac{606}{15}&\small\gray{\text{Rewrite the division as a fraction.}}\\\\ &=\dfrac{202}{5} \times \dfrac{3}{3}&\small\gray{\text{Rewrite as a product.}}\\\\ &=\dfrac{202}{5} \times 1&\small\gray{\text{Simplify.}}\\\\ &=\dfrac{200 + 2}{5}&\small\gray{\text{Split 202 into 200 and 2.}}\\\\ &=\dfrac{200}{5} + \dfrac{2}{5}&\small\gray{\text{Break into two fractions.}}\\\\ &=40 + \dfrac{2}{5}&\small\gray{\text{Simplify.}}\\\\ &=40 + 0.4 &\small\gray{\text{Write as a decimal.}} \end{align}$

$\begin{align} 606 \div 15&=\dfrac{606}{15}&\small\gray{\text{Rewrite the division as a fraction.}}\\\\ &=\dfrac{202}{5} \times \dfrac{3}{3}&\small\gray{\text{Rewrite as a product.}}\\\\ &=\dfrac{202}{5} \times 1&\small\gray{\text{Simplify.}}\\\\ &=\dfrac{200 + 2}{5}&\small\gray{\text{Split 202 into 200 and 2.}}\\\\ &=\dfrac{200}{5} + \dfrac{2}{5}&\small\gray{\text{Break into two fractions.}}\\\\ &=40 + \dfrac{2}{5}&\small\gray{\text{Simplify.}}\\\\ &=40 + 0.4 &\small\gray{\text{Write as a decimal.}}\\\\ &=40.4 \end{align}$
Let's rewrite the division problem as a fraction. Then we can rewrite the fraction with $100$ in the denominator.
$\begin{align} 464 \div 25&=\dfrac{464}{25}&\small\gray{\text{Rewrite the division as a fraction.}} \end{align}$
$\begin{align} 464 \div 25&=\dfrac{464}{25}&\small\gray{\text{Rewrite the division as a fraction.}}\\\\ &=\dfrac{464}{25} \times 1&\small\gray{\text{Rewrite as a product.}} \end{align}$

$\begin{align} 464 \div 25&=\dfrac{464}{25}&\small\gray{\text{Rewrite the division as a fraction.}}\\\\ &=\dfrac{464}{25} \times 1&\small\gray{\text{Rewrite as a product.}}\\\\ &=\dfrac{464}{25} \times \dfrac{4}{4}&\small\gray{\text{Rewrite with equivalent fraction.}} \end{align}$

$\begin{align} 464 \div 25&=\dfrac{464}{25}&\small\gray{\text{Rewrite the division as a fraction.}}\\\\ &=\dfrac{464}{25} \times 1&\small\gray{\text{Rewrite as a product.}}\\\\ &=\dfrac{464}{25} \times \dfrac{4}{4}&\small\gray{\text{Rewrite with equivalent fraction.}}\\\\ &=\dfrac{1{,}856}{100}&\small\gray{\text{Rewrite with }100\text{ as denominator.}} \end{align}$

$\begin{align} 464 \div 25&=\dfrac{464}{25}&\small\gray{\text{Rewrite the division as a fraction.}}\\\\ &=\dfrac{464}{25} \times 1&\small\gray{\text{Rewrite as a product.}}\\\\ &=\dfrac{464}{25} \times \dfrac{4}{4}&\small\gray{\text{Rewrite with equivalent fraction.}}\\\\ &=\dfrac{1{,}856}{100}&\small\gray{\text{Rewrite with }100\text{ as denominator.}}\\\\ &=18.56&\small\gray{\text{Write as a decimal.}} \end{align}$
Let's rewrite the division problem as a fraction. Then we can split the fraction into better known fractions.
$\begin{align} 600 \div 80&=\dfrac{600}{80}&\small\gray{\text{Rewrite the division as a fraction.}} \end{align}$
$\begin{align} 600 \div 80&=\dfrac{600}{80}&\small\gray{\text{Rewrite the division as a fraction.}}\\\\ &=\dfrac{6}{8} \times \dfrac{100}{10}&\small\gray{\text{Rewrite as a product.}} \end{align}$

$\begin{align} 600 \div 80&=\dfrac{600}{80}&\small\gray{\text{Rewrite the division as a fraction.}}\\\\ &=\dfrac{6}{8} \times \dfrac{100}{10}&\small\gray{\text{Rewrite as a product.}}\\\\ &=\dfrac{3}{4} \times 10&\small\gray{\text{Simplify.}} \end{align}$

$\begin{align} 600 \div 80&=\dfrac{600}{80}&\small\gray{\text{Rewrite the division as a fraction.}}\\\\ &=\dfrac{6}{8} \times \dfrac{100}{10}&\small\gray{\text{Rewrite as a product.}}\\\\ &=\dfrac{3}{4} \times 10&\small\gray{\text{Simplify.}}\\\\ &=0.75 \times 10 &\small\gray{\text{Write as a decimal.}} \end{align}$

$\begin{align} 600 \div 80&=\dfrac{600}{80}&\small\gray{\text{Rewrite the division as a fraction.}}\\\\ &=\dfrac{6}{8} \times \dfrac{100}{10}&\small\gray{\text{Rewrite as a product.}}\\\\ &=\dfrac{3}{4} \times 10&\small\gray{\text{Simplify.}}\\\\ &=0.75 \times 10 &\small\gray{\text{Write as a decimal.}}\\\\ &=7.5 \end{align}$
Let's rewrite the division problem as a fraction. Then we can split the fraction into better known fractions.
$\begin{align} 50 \div 40&=\dfrac{50}{40}&\small\gray{\text{Rewrite the division as a fraction.}} \end{align}$
$\begin{align} 50 \div 40&=\dfrac{50}{40}&\small\gray{\text{Rewrite the division as a fraction.}}\\\\ &=\dfrac{5}{4} \times \dfrac{10}{10}&\small\gray{\text{Rewrite as a product.}} \end{align}$

$\begin{align} 50 \div 40&=\dfrac{50}{40}&\small\gray{\text{Rewrite the division as a fraction.}}\\\\ &=\dfrac{5}{4} \times \dfrac{10}{10}&\small\gray{\text{Rewrite as a product.}}\\\\ &=\dfrac{5}{4} \times 1&\small\gray{\text{Simplify.}} \end{align}$

$\begin{align} 50 \div 40&=\dfrac{50}{40}&\small\gray{\text{Rewrite the division as a fraction.}}\\\\ &=\dfrac{5}{4} \times \dfrac{10}{10}&\small\gray{\text{Rewrite as a product.}}\\\\ &=\dfrac{5}{4} \times 1&\small\gray{\text{Simplify.}}\\\\ &=\dfrac{4 + 1}{4}&\small\gray{\text{Split 5 into 4 and 1.}} \end{align}$

$\begin{align} 50 \div 40&=\dfrac{50}{40}&\small\gray{\text{Rewrite the division as a fraction.}}\\\\ &=\dfrac{5}{4} \times \dfrac{10}{10}&\small\gray{\text{Rewrite as a product.}}\\\\ &=\dfrac{5}{4} \times 1&\small\gray{\text{Simplify.}}\\\\ &=\dfrac{4 + 1}{4}&\small\gray{\text{Split 5 into 4 and 1.}}\\\\ &=\dfrac{4}{4} + \dfrac{1}{4}&\small\gray{\text{Break into two fractions.}} \end{align}$

$\begin{align} 50 \div 40&=\dfrac{50}{40}&\small\gray{\text{Rewrite the division as a fraction.}}\\\\ &=\dfrac{5}{4} \times \dfrac{10}{10}&\small\gray{\text{Rewrite as a product.}}\\\\ &=\dfrac{5}{4} \times 1&\small\gray{\text{Simplify.}}\\\\ &=\dfrac{4 + 1}{4}&\small\gray{\text{Split 5 into 4 and 1.}}\\\\ &=\dfrac{4}{4} + \dfrac{1}{4}&\small\gray{\text{Break into two fractions.}}\\\\ &=1 + \dfrac{1}{4}&\small\gray{\text{Simplify.}} \end{align}$

$\begin{align} 50 \div 40&=\dfrac{50}{40}&\small\gray{\text{Rewrite the division as a fraction.}}\\\\ &=\dfrac{5}{4} \times \dfrac{10}{10}&\small\gray{\text{Rewrite as a product.}}\\\\ &=\dfrac{5}{4} \times 1&\small\gray{\text{Simplify.}}\\\\ &=\dfrac{4 + 1}{4}&\small\gray{\text{Split 5 into 4 and 1.}}\\\\ &=\dfrac{4}{4} + \dfrac{1}{4}&\small\gray{\text{Break into two fractions.}}\\\\ &=1 + \dfrac{1}{4}&\small\gray{\text{Simplify.}}\\\\ &=1 + 0.25&\small\gray{\text{Write as a decimal.}} \end{align}$

$\begin{align} 50 \div 40&=\dfrac{50}{40}&\small\gray{\text{Rewrite the division as a fraction.}}\\\\ &=\dfrac{5}{4} \times \dfrac{10}{10}&\small\gray{\text{Rewrite as a product.}}\\\\ &=\dfrac{5}{4} \times 1&\small\gray{\text{Simplify.}}\\\\ &=\dfrac{4 + 1}{4}&\small\gray{\text{Split 5 into 4 and 1.}}\\\\ &=\dfrac{4}{4} + \dfrac{1}{4}&\small\gray{\text{Break into two fractions.}}\\\\ &=1 + \dfrac{1}{4}&\small\gray{\text{Simplify.}}\\\\ &=1 + 0.25&\small\gray{\text{Write as a decimal.}}\\\\ &=1.25 \end{align}$
Let's rewrite the division problem as a fraction. Then we can split the fraction into better known fractions.
$\begin{align} 20 \div 80 &= \dfrac{20}{80}&\small\gray{\text{Rewrite the division as a fraction.}} \end{align}$
$\begin{align} 20 \div 80 &= \dfrac{20}{80}&\small\gray{\text{Rewrite the division as a fraction.}}\\\\ &=  \dfrac{2}{8} \times \dfrac{10}{10}&\small\gray{\text{Rewrite as a product.}} \end{align}$

$\begin{align} 20 \div 80 &= \dfrac{20}{80}&\small\gray{\text{Rewrite the division as a fraction.}}\\\\ &=  \dfrac{2}{8} \times \dfrac{10}{10}&\small\gray{\text{Rewrite as a product.}}\\\\ &=\dfrac{1}{4} \times 1& \small\gray{\text{ Simplify.}} \end{align}$

$\begin{align} 20 \div 80 &= \dfrac{20}{80}&\small\gray{\text{Rewrite the division as a fraction.}}\\\\ &=  \dfrac{2}{8} \times \dfrac{10}{10}&\small\gray{\text{Rewrite as a product.}}\\\\ &=\dfrac{1}{4} \times 1& \small\gray{\text{ Simplify.}}\\\\ &= 0.25&  \small\gray{\text{Write as a decimal.}} \end{align}$
Let's rewrite the division problem as a fraction. Then we can split the fraction into better known fractions.
$\begin{align} 57 \div 75 &= \dfrac{57}{75}&\small\gray{\text{Rewrite the division as a fraction.}} \end{align}$
$\begin{align} 57 \div 75 &= \dfrac{57}{75}&\small\gray{\text{Rewrite the division as a fraction.}}\\\\ &=  \dfrac{19}{25} \times \dfrac{3}{3}&\small\gray{\text{Rewrite as a product.}} \end{align}$

$\begin{align} 57 \div 75 &= \dfrac{57}{75}&\small\gray{\text{Rewrite the division as a fraction.}}\\\\ &=  \dfrac{19}{25} \times \dfrac{3}{3}&\small\gray{\text{Rewrite as a product.}}\\\\ &=  \dfrac{19}{25} \times \dfrac{4}{4}&\small\gray{\text{Rewrite with equivalent fraction.}} \end{align}$

$\begin{align} 57 \div 75 &= \dfrac{57}{75}&\small\gray{\text{Rewrite the division as a fraction.}}\\\\ &=  \dfrac{19}{25} \times \dfrac{3}{3}&\small\gray{\text{Rewrite as a product.}}\\\\ &=  \dfrac{19}{25} \times \dfrac{4}{4}&\small\gray{\text{Rewrite with equivalent fraction.}}\\\\ &=\dfrac{76}{100}& \small\gray{\text{Rewrite with 100 as denominator.}} \end{align}$

$\begin{align} 57 \div 75 &= \dfrac{57}{75}&\small\gray{\text{Rewrite the division as a fraction.}}\\\\ &=  \dfrac{19}{25} \times \dfrac{3}{3}&\small\gray{\text{Rewrite as a product.}}\\\\ &=  \dfrac{19}{25} \times \dfrac{4}{4}&\small\gray{\text{Rewrite with equivalent fraction.}}\\\\ &=\dfrac{76}{100}& \small\gray{\text{Rewrite with 100 as denominator.}}\\\\ &= 0.76&  \small\gray{\text{Write as a decimal.}} \end{align}$
Let's rewrite the division problem as a fraction. Then we can split the fraction into better known fractions.
$\begin{align} 9 \div 45 &= \dfrac{9}{45}&\small\gray{\text{Rewrite the division as a fraction.}} \end{align}$
$\begin{align} 9 \div 45 &= \dfrac{9}{45}&\small\gray{\text{Rewrite the division as a fraction.}}\\\\ &=  \dfrac{1}{5} \times \dfrac{9}{9}&\small\gray{\text{Rewrite as a product.}} \end{align}$

$\begin{align} 9 \div 45 &= \dfrac{9}{45}&\small\gray{\text{Rewrite the division as a fraction.}}\\\\ &=  \dfrac{1}{5} \times \dfrac{9}{9}&\small\gray{\text{Rewrite as a product.}}\\\\ &=  \dfrac{1}{5} \times \dfrac{2}{2}&\small\gray{\text{Rewrite with equivalent fraction.}} \end{align}$

$\begin{align} 9 \div 45 &= \dfrac{9}{45}&\small\gray{\text{Rewrite the division as a fraction.}}\\\\ &=  \dfrac{1}{5} \times \dfrac{9}{9}&\small\gray{\text{Rewrite as a product.}}\\\\ &=  \dfrac{1}{5} \times \dfrac{2}{2}&\small\gray{\text{Rewrite with equivalent fraction.}}\\\\ &=\dfrac{2}{10}& \small\gray{\text{Rewrite with 10 as denominator.}} \end{align}$

$\begin{align} 9 \div 45 &= \dfrac{9}{45}&\small\gray{\text{Rewrite the division as a fraction.}}\\\\ &=  \dfrac{1}{5} \times \dfrac{9}{9}&\small\gray{\text{Rewrite as a product.}}\\\\ &=  \dfrac{1}{5} \times \dfrac{2}{2}&\small\gray{\text{Rewrite with equivalent fraction.}}\\\\ &=\dfrac{2}{10}& \small\gray{\text{Rewrite with 10 as denominator.}}\\\\ &= 0.2&  \small\gray{\text{Write as a decimal.}} \end{align}$
Let's rewrite the division problem as a fraction. Then we can split the fraction into better known fractions.
$\begin{align} 7 \div 25 &= \dfrac{7}{25}&\small\gray{\text{Rewrite the division as a fraction.}} \end{align}$
$\begin{align} 7 \div 25 &= \dfrac{7}{25}&\small\gray{\text{Rewrite the division as a fraction.}}\\\\ &=  \dfrac{7}{25} \times 1&\small\gray{\text{Rewrite as a product.}} \end{align}$

$\begin{align} 7 \div 25 &= \dfrac{7}{25}&\small\gray{\text{Rewrite the division as a fraction.}}\\\\ &=  \dfrac{7}{25} \times 1&\small\gray{\text{Rewrite as a product.}}\\\\ &=  \dfrac{7}{25} \times \dfrac{4}{4}&\small\gray{\text{Rewrite with equivalent fraction.}} \end{align}$

$\begin{align} 7 \div 25 &= \dfrac{7}{25}&\small\gray{\text{Rewrite the division as a fraction.}}\\\\ &=  \dfrac{7}{25} \times 1&\small\gray{\text{Rewrite as a product.}}\\\\ &=  \dfrac{7}{25} \times \dfrac{4}{4}&\small\gray{\text{Rewrite with equivalent fraction.}}\\\\ &=\dfrac{28}{100}& \small\gray{\text{Rewrite with 100 as denominator.}} \end{align}$

$\begin{align} 7 \div 25 &= \dfrac{7}{25}&\small\gray{\text{Rewrite the division as a fraction.}}\\\\ &=  \dfrac{7}{25} \times 1&\small\gray{\text{Rewrite as a product.}}\\\\ &=  \dfrac{7}{25} \times \dfrac{4}{4}&\small\gray{\text{Rewrite with equivalent fraction.}}\\\\ &=\dfrac{28}{100}& \small\gray{\text{Rewrite with 100 as denominator.}}\\\\ &= 0.28&  \small\gray{\text{Write as a decimal.}} \end{align}$
Let's rewrite the division problem as a fraction. Then we can split the fraction into better known fractions.
$\begin{align} 3 \div 50 &= \dfrac{3}{50}&\small\gray{\text{Rewrite the division as a fraction.}} \end{align}$
$\begin{align} 3 \div 50 &= \dfrac{3}{50}&\small\gray{\text{Rewrite the division as a fraction.}}\\\\ &=  \dfrac{3}{50} \times 1&\small\gray{\text{Rewrite as a product.}} \end{align}$

$\begin{align} 3 \div 50 &= \dfrac{3}{50}&\small\gray{\text{Rewrite the division as a fraction.}}\\\\ &=  \dfrac{3}{50} \times 1&\small\gray{\text{Rewrite as a product.}}\\\\ &=  \dfrac{3}{50} \times \dfrac{2}{2}&\small\gray{\text{Rewrite with equivalent fraction.}} \end{align}$

$\begin{align} 3 \div 50 &= \dfrac{3}{50}&\small\gray{\text{Rewrite the division as a fraction.}}\\\\ &=  \dfrac{3}{50} \times 1&\small\gray{\text{Rewrite as a product.}}\\\\ &=  \dfrac{3}{50} \times \dfrac{2}{2}&\small\gray{\text{Rewrite with equivalent fraction.}}\\\\ &=\dfrac{6}{100}& \small\gray{\text{Rewrite with 100 as denominator.}} \end{align}$

$\begin{align} 3 \div 50 &= \dfrac{3}{50}&\small\gray{\text{Rewrite the division as a fraction.}}\\\\ &=  \dfrac{3}{50} \times 1&\small\gray{\text{Rewrite as a product.}}\\\\ &=  \dfrac{3}{50} \times \dfrac{2}{2}&\small\gray{\text{Rewrite with equivalent fraction.}}\\\\ &=\dfrac{6}{100}& \small\gray{\text{Rewrite with 100 as denominator.}}\\\\ &= 0.06&  \small\gray{\text{Write as a decimal.}} \end{align}$
Let's rewrite the division problem as a fraction. Then we can split the fraction into better known fractions.
$\begin{align} 21 \div 28 &= \dfrac{21}{28}&\small\gray{\text{Rewrite the division as a fraction.}} \end{align}$
$\begin{align} 21 \div 28 &= \dfrac{21}{28}&\small\gray{\text{Rewrite the division as a fraction.}}\\\\ &=  \dfrac{3}{4} \times \dfrac{7}{7}&\small\gray{\text{Rewrite as a product.}} \end{align}$

$\begin{align} 21 \div 28 &= \dfrac{21}{28}&\small\gray{\text{Rewrite the division as a fraction.}}\\\\ &=  \dfrac{3}{4} \times \dfrac{7}{7}&\small\gray{\text{Rewrite as a product.}}\\\\ &=  \dfrac{3}{4} \times 1&\small\gray{\text{Simplify.}} \end{align}$

$\begin{align} 21 \div 28 &= \dfrac{21}{28}&\small\gray{\text{Rewrite the division as a fraction.}}\\\\ &=  \dfrac{3}{4} \times \dfrac{7}{7}&\small\gray{\text{Rewrite as a product.}}\\\\ &=  \dfrac{3}{4} \times 1&\small\gray{\text{Simplify.}}\\\\ &= 0.75&  \small\gray{\text{Write as a decimal.}} \end{align}$
Let's rewrite the division problem as a fraction. Then we can split the fraction into better known fractions.
$\begin{align} 19 \div 38 &= \dfrac{19}{38}&\small\gray{\text{Rewrite the division as a fraction.}} \end{align}$
$\begin{align} 19 \div 38 &= \dfrac{19}{38}&\small\gray{\text{Rewrite the division as a fraction.}}\\\\ &=  \dfrac{1}{2} \times \dfrac{19}{19}&\small\gray{\text{Rewrite as a product.}} \end{align}$

$\begin{align} 19 \div 38 &= \dfrac{19}{38}&\small\gray{\text{Rewrite the division as a fraction.}}\\\\ &=  \dfrac{1}{2} \times \dfrac{19}{19}&\small\gray{\text{Rewrite as a product.}}\\\\ &=  \dfrac{1}{2} \times 1&\small\gray{\text{Simplify.}} \end{align}$

$\begin{align} 19 \div 38 &= \dfrac{19}{38}&\small\gray{\text{Rewrite the division as a fraction.}}\\\\ &=  \dfrac{1}{2} \times \dfrac{19}{19}&\small\gray{\text{Rewrite as a product.}}\\\\ &=  \dfrac{1}{2} \times 1&\small\gray{\text{Simplify.}}\\\\ &= 0.5&  \small\gray{\text{Write as a decimal.}} \end{align}$
Let's rewrite the division problem as a fraction. Then we can split the fraction into better known fractions.
$\begin{align} 20 \div 40 &= \dfrac{20}{40}&\small\gray{\text{Rewrite the division as a fraction.}} \end{align}$
$\begin{align} 20 \div 40 &= \dfrac{20}{40}&\small\gray{\text{Rewrite the division as a fraction.}}\\\\ &=  \dfrac{2}{4} \times \dfrac{10}{10}&\small\gray{\text{Rewrite as a product.}} \end{align}$

$\begin{align} 20 \div 40 &= \dfrac{20}{40}&\small\gray{\text{Rewrite the division as a fraction.}}\\\\ &=  \dfrac{2}{4} \times \dfrac{10}{10}&\small\gray{\text{Rewrite as a product.}}\\\\ &=\dfrac{1}{2} \times 1& \small\gray{\text{ Simplify.}} \end{align}$

$\begin{align} 20 \div 40 &= \dfrac{20}{40}&\small\gray{\text{Rewrite the division as a fraction.}}\\\\ &=  \dfrac{2}{4} \times \dfrac{10}{10}&\small\gray{\text{Rewrite as a product.}}\\\\ &=\dfrac{1}{2} \times 1& \small\gray{\text{ Simplify.}}\\\\ &= 0.5&  \small\gray{\text{Write as a decimal.}} \end{align}$
